title: First meeting of the Guernsey R Users Group
text:
Date: Wednesday 24 August
Time: 1230 - 1330
Location: The Shed at the Digital Greenhouse
Sign up: On Eventbrite

In this first meeting, we will be meeting other R users on the island and covering the aims of the Guernsey R Users Group.
As this probably won’t take the full time, we’ll round off with a quick overview of some of R’s object systems, focusing on S3, S4 and the in-development R7.
If you want to join us, sign up on at the Eventbrite page.
Hope to see you there.

Slides for the first presentation:


And for the second:

title: Making Good Graphs with ggplot2
text:
Date: 30 June
Presenter: Michael Jones
Time: 1230 - 1330
Location: The Shed, Digital Greenhouse, Guernsey
Sign up on EventBrite

title: Making Good Graphs with ggplot2
text:
Abstract
Making your graph is only the first step, you also have to make it nice to look at. ggplot2 and the related ecosystem of packages provide a wealth of tools to help you do just that. We’ll cover a few conventions, some colour theory, some views on what makes good visualisations, and some other resources to learn from, practice with, and be inspired by.
Slides for the presentation:

title: Getting Better at R by Solving Puzzles
text:
Date: 12 December 2023
Presenter: Michael Jones
Time: 1230 - 1330
Location: The Shed, Digital Greenhouse, Guernsey
Sign up on EventBrite

title: Getting Better at R by Solving Puzzles
text:
Abstract
Each year during December, thousands of people across the world take part in Advent of Code. This is a fantastic series of themed puzzles released each day throughout December up to Christmas. In this session we’ll solve the first few puzzles from 2023’s event together.
I’m hoping to offer this as a hybrid event with the ability to join via Google Meet. While I hope you will attend in person, everyone who signs up will receive a link to the call so you can attend even if you can’t be there in person.
If you want to try the puzzles before the session, please do! In fact, if you want, you can join the private leaderboard to compete on solving these puzzles the quickest. The puzzles are language-agnostic, so you can use whatever language you feel most comfortable in, though in the session we’ll only be using R. Sign up to the leaderboard here using the code: 1114872-105538e6. If you signed up last year, you’ll still be listed here.

title: Running your own CRAN
text:
Date: 22 March
Presenter: Adam Rawles
Time: 1230 - 1330
Location: The Shed, Digital Greenhouse, Guernsey
Sign up on EventBrite

title: Running your own CRAN
text:
Abstract
Ever looked at the CRAN package repository and thought ‘Wow, I wish I could do something like that but worse’? Well look no further! In this talk I’ll outline how I built a CRAN-like R package repository using a continuous integration platform and the {plumber} package. I’ll discuss the difference between source and binary packages in how they’re stored and handled by a package repository, how I integrated the {pkgdown} package to integrate documentation with the repository and all the mistakes I made along the way.

title: Running your own CRAN
text:
Speaker
I’m Adam, a Data Scientist, and I’ve used R for around 6 years now. I’ve used R for everything from modelling and machine learning to backend APIs and user interfaces and I’ve written two books on the language. More recently I’ve also dabbled in productionising and containerising R code for larger scale applications.

title: Running your own CRAN
Dealing with Bugs
text:
Date: Tuesday 29 November
Presenter: Michael Jones
Time: 1230 - 1330
Location: The Shed at the Digital Greenhouse

Sign up at Eventbrite
Write enough code and bugs are inevitable. In this session we’ll cover:

Using R and RStudio’s debugging features to track bugs and errors in your and other people’s code
Defensive strategies to employ in your own code to catch errors as or before they occur
Ways to rethink errors by adjusting the type of things your functions return

Slides for the presentation:

title: teachR Book Club
text:
Our own Adam Rawles has written an introductory book on R available for free here: https://teacher.arawles.co.uk/
We’re going to run this as a series of informal discussion sessions. Each session will be advertised in advance, and the notice will include what chapters we’re going to cover. You should ideally read the chapters before attending the meeting as we will talk around the chapter, maybe cover a few exercises and discuss putting the content into practice.
These sessions are likely to be run remotely via Zoom or Teams or similar.
More information coming soon.

title: About
text:
The Guernsey R Users Group is in the process of being set up.
Any questions, please email guernseyrusersgroup@gmail.com.

title: Guernsey R Users Group
text:
This is the website of the Guernsey R Users Group. We’ll post talk materials and details of events here as they are organised.
You can see our upcoming and past events on the events page.
If you would like to join us, would like to present, or would like to ask any questions, please do email guernseyrusersgroup@gmail.com or fill in the forms below.
